LB Page 1 /6 ENIAC Steering Committee Draft Minutes of the 2nd meeting Recorder of the Minutes: Livio Baldi Tel.: +39.039.6035015 Fax: +39.039.6035055 Email: livio.baldi@st.com Date: 23 November 2005 Location: Barcelona (cid:131) Opening comments (cid:131) Changes in composition of Steering Committee (cid:131) Status of ENIAC (cid:131) New member applications (cid:131) Presentation of SRA (cid:131) Presentation of Scientific Council and Research Infrastructures (cid:131) Update from the Commission on FP7 and JTIs (cid:131) Next Steering Committee meeting (cid:131) A.o.b (cid:131) Wrap-up and closing remarks Participants: ENIAC Steering Committee: STMicroelectronics Philips semiconductors MEDEA+ Apologies: Infineon Philips Robert Bosch Thales Thomson ASM-L IMEC Observers: Public Authorities (NL) EC DG INFSO EC DG RTD Pasquale Pistorio (Chair) Alain Dutheil Arthur van der Poel (Wolfgang Ziebart) (Frans van Houten) (Sigfried Dais) (Denis Ranque) (Claude Barraud) (Eric Meurice) (Gilbert Declerck) Ben Ruck Rainer Zimmerman Michel Hordies Dirk Beernaert Heico Frima ENIAC Technical Assistants: Livio Baldi Fred van Rosmalen Gerard Matheron Delegate Norbert Lehner Theo Claasen Peter van Staa Francois Levieux Guy Gerot Rob Hartman Roger De Keersmaecker 05-11-30 ENIAC Steering Committee Decisions / Actions list: WHAT WHO WHEN LB Page 2 /6 1. Changes in Steering Committee composition accepted 2. AMIS, Indesit, SEMI and Umicore accepted as new members of ENIAC Forum of Stakeholders. 3. National ENIAC consortia can be accepted in Forum, if there is a clear industrial component, and no other national representative is present. 4. SRA will be inserted in web node 5. SRA must be widely circulated 6. WG Research Infrastructures is accepted 7. Next Steering Committee meeting M.Hordies November 2005 All Philips ASAP November 2005 Early February 2006 Draft minutes of the 2nd ENIAC Steering Committee meeting on 23 November 2005 in Fira Palace Hotel, Barcelona 1. Opening: Mr. Pistorio opens the meeting and welcomes all participants. All participants receive a copy of the Strategic Research Agenda. In a tour de table they all introduce themselves. The Chairman introduces the meeting, pointing out that all the main activities he committed to in June 2004 to set up the Technology Platform Nanoelectronics and ENIAC have been completed, even if it took almost 18 months instead of one year. The Steering Committee has been formed, the organization has been defined and there is now also the Strategic Research Agenda. He introduces a philosophical note: Europe is late with respect to the rate of evolution of the rest of the world. If it wants to keep its standard of living, it must move fast and Nanoelectronics is a key enabling technology. MEDEA+, and JESSI before it, has made a good job, maintaining a strong Microelectronics industry. Now the same must be done at European level, ensuring cooperation. ENIAC and MEDEA+ must continue cooperating, avoiding duplication. There are severe threats to the planned budget of the Commission, coming from national states. The 1% national contribution to the Commission budget is too low to support growth, and Research risks being penalized by entrenched interest. Europe must stop supporting the past and look at the future. 2. Changes in composition of Steering Committee 05-11-30 ENIAC Steering Committee LB Page 3 /6 The Chairman reminds that in June 2004 he accepted the position for one year, then he agreed to extend it to complete the SRA. Now that all major initial targets have been achieved, he intends to leave his mandate. As his replacement in the Steering Committee he proposes A. Dutheil, COO of STMIcroelectronics, and ST representative in MEDEA+ Board, thus confirming the cohesion between the two organization. On this occasion also the rotation of Chairmanship should be implemented. Next Chairman should be F. van Houten of Philips Semiconductors, to be followed by Infineon. Chairmanship rotation should be yearly, at least in the first phase. The Steering Committee approves and thanks Pistorio for his work. Th. Claasen accepts the Chairmanship in the name of F. van Houten. N. Lehner confirms the commitment of Infineon and clarifies that W. Ziebart will continue to represent both branches of Infineon, after the recently announced split. For the Public Authorities B. Ruck announces that E. Caquot has been replaced by E. Gabla, who confirms his commitment to the Mirror Group. In the European Commission, R. Zimmerman is replaced by D. Beernaert at the head of the Microelectronics Unit. No other changes are announced (Annex 1). L.Baldi announces that, following the rotation of Chairmanship, F. van Roosmalen will now coordinate the ENIAC Support Group, while he will take care of the Strategic Research Agenda. 3. Status of ENIAC L.Baldi then introduces the status of ENIAC (see Annex 2). The SRA has been presented on September 16 at ESSDERC in Grenoble, with a good audience (around 75 people), and now the text version is available, and will be distributed to the Forum. A Support Action has been approved by the European Commission to finance the ENIAC Office. The Office will be located in the same building as the MEDEA+ one in Paris, to improve coordination and reduce costs. The financing covers the expenses for the first two years. Afterwards it will be up to the ENIAC members. The selection of the Office Director is in progress and should be completed in a couple of weeks. The Scientific Council is in evolution and a proposal will be presented to reinforce it. Also a new Working Group on Research Infrastructures will be proposed. The relationships with other European Technology Platforms are presented. Up to now links have been established with other existing ICT Platforms (ARTEMIS, E-Mobility, NEM and NESSI) in order to define a common frame SRA for ICT and avoid duplication. A definition of fields of competence and interfaces has been agreed upon with ARTEMIS. Two new Platforms are in definition: Photonics and Smart System Integration (EPOSS). For the latter there could be some overlap. ENIAC has already participated in a joint meeting to better define activities. DG Research has approved a Coordination Action to interface SMEs with Platforms. First contacts have been taken with WP4, in charge of ICT Platforms. 4. New applications Three new Companies have applied for joining ENIAC Forum of Stakeholders. They are Umicore (Belgium), a chemical Company, Indesit (Italy) a white good producer and AMIS (Belgium) an US semiconductor manufacturer with strong production and R&D activities in Europe. Documentation has been submitted by the Companies (Annexes 3-6). Also SEMI Europe has shown interest in joining ENIAC, but due to a change in its Chairmanship, the documentation has been submitted too late, and could not be circulated in advance (Annex 7). ICI (GB), another chemical Company, has withdrawn its request for association, but it has asked to be kept informed. P.Pistorio comments that it is important to make ENIAC more representative of the sector, increasing participation, even if the Steering Committee must be kept small and efficient, and proposes to accept the new applicants. P.Van Staa observes that it should not be enough to be economically involved with Nanoelectronics to become member of ENIAC, but a more active participation is required. P.Pistorio agrees to the comment and asks that new members should be notified that they must actively participate in the growth of Nanoelectronics in Europe. He 05-11-30 ENIAC Steering Committee 5. Presentation of SRA F.van Roosmalen introduces the Strategic Research Agenda (Annex 8), aiming to cover all aspects of Nanoelectronics Research in Europe, starting from a close link with the Society needs and the applications. On possible JTIs P.Pistorio comments that JESSI and MEDEA+ did a great job in the past and their experience should not go lost. If there are JTIs in the same field of MEDEA+, they should be jointly managed. Also he points out that Environment is not explicitly mentioned among the drivers. Here is a field where Nanoelectronics could give a great contribution especially in saving energy. D. Beernaert also comments that there is no mention of Manufacturing. It should be included in future versions. Also Opto-electronics has not been considered. The Steering Committee congratulates with F. Van Roosmalen for the impressive work, and P.Pistorio recommends that the document should be widely circulated and advertised, especially towards public authorities. Forum members will be asked to do the same. The Commission (M.Hordies) is requested to insert the SRA on the ENIAC web node. 6. Scientific Council and Research Infrastructures LB Page 4 /6 also proposes that all ENIAC members are asked to provide a yearly status of their contribution to the progress of Nanoelectronics. With these comments the new members are accepted. L.Baldi raises the problem of European countries not being represented in the Forum, because they do not have any strong industry or Research Center. Austria has solved the problem, by forming a national Nanoelectronics association, involving SMEs and Academia, which is very active, has established strong ties with the Mirror Group and has contributed to SRA. Also Spain is moving in the same direction. He proposes to accept representative of these organizations in the Forum when the country is not otherwise present. The proposal is accepted, but conditioned to a strong industrial component. Otherwise their place is the Council of Scientific Community. R. Zimmermann warns that also Associated States must be considered, if they show a strong Commitment. R. De Keersmaecker presents the status of the Council of Scientific Community (Annex 9). Two meetings have been held, with a large participation. However not all countries have formally selected their representatives. A proposal for extension is presented, to achieve better links with the Working Groups and especially the one on SRA. Some concern about the size of the final structure. It is observed that it should be just a consulting structure, and a link with Academia, and should not become a parallel governing body. The proposal for WG Research Infrastructures is presented (Annex 10). The WG already had several meetings to take profit of the ESFRI opening for proposals. The PRINS proposal for Nanoelectronics seems to be in good position. Th. Claasen remarks that we must be sure that funding is feasible, otherwise all the activity will be only a loss of time. R.Zimmermann answers that funding is foreseen in FP VII under the Capacity program. Of course cuts to overall budget could severely affect it. R.De Keersmaecker asks the Steering Committee to approve the mandate and timing proposed for the new WG. The request is positively answered. 7. Update from the Commission on FP7 and JTIs D. Beernaert presents the Commissions view on ETPs and JTIs (Annex 11), and their status. ENIAC has reached Stage 2 (Definition of SRA) and is moving towards Stage 3 (Implementation). A JTI could cover part of the SRA with a joint undertaking under Article 171. Nanoelectronics is one of the subjects foreseen for JTIs, but there will be strong competition on funding, therefore a strong, realistic and convincing case must be made. It is foreseen that JTI 05-11-30 ENIAC Steering Committee LB Page 5 /6 will cover only part of the SRA and the rest should be implemented through conventional instruments, either under FP VII or in national and trans-national programs. PAs have made anyhow clear that there will not be double funding and would like to avoid that different funding mechanisms exist next to each other. Simple, flexible, straight forward approaches avoiding red tape are also in their interest. Key factors will be the importance of the topic selected, the industrial commitment, and the capacity to attract also academia and SMEs and the support by different national governments. A top-up funding scheme is foreseen to stimulate more resources in this strategic field and to facilitate implementation of an efficient cooperation scheme. A common working model is discussed with ARTEMIS. A decision is expected between February and March, therefore it is important to move quickly. P. Pistorio remarks that a 3% investment in Research will not be enough to keep Europe competitive. A most aggressive target around 5% is needed. Simplicity is important. The French Agence pour lInnovation could be a good model. D.Beernaert points out that a strong industrial commitment is needed: a private/public rate of 2:1, as in Lisbon objective, would be advisable. The need to sell this initiative and the SRA to a broad community and to the different authorities was also highlighted. 8. Next Steering Committee meeting Given the uncertainty in funding and the tight schedule for JTI, a meeting of the Steering Committee is needed early in February 2006, to approve the proposal for JTI. It is remarked that to achieve maximum impact the members of the Steering Committee should attend personally and avoid delegation. F. van Houten (Philips) is asked to organize the next meeting, possibly in Brussels and in the second week of February. Proposed dates are Feb. 7 or 8. 9. A.o.B No other issue is raised. 10. Wrap-up and closing remarks Mr. Pistorio warmly thanks all participants and expresses his best wishes for the successful continuation of ENIAC. 05-11-30 ENIAC Steering Committee
